Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Effects of Stress on Onset of Middle Childhood among Aka Foragers and Ngandu Horticulturalists

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Current theory proposes that human childhood is an assessment phase where children use their experience with risk or unpredictability (e.g., stressors) to shape future life history strategies. This suggests that timing of developmental transitions may depend on experience in the preceding phase. Doctoral student Courtney Helfrecht (Washington State University), under the guidance of Dr. Courtney Meehan, tests the hypothesis that early experience of stress has significant effects on age of onset for middle childhood and its biological correlate (adrenarche) among Aka foragers and Ngandu horticulturalists of the Central African Republic (CAR). Initial data indicate that middle childhood is a culturally-defined phase associated with changes in cognitive and social abilities. This research builds from that with three additional goals: 1) assessment of cultural and environmental stressors; 2) determination of chronological age of onset for middle childhood and adrenarche; and 3) evaluation of which stressors affect timing of onset for both middle childhood and adrenarche.

This integrative study is among the first to empirically examine this relationship using observational, hormonal, interview, demographic, and cross-cultural data. An initial collection of hair samples provides population profiles for timing of adrenarche using hair hormone analysis, conducted via collaboration between Washington State University and The George Washington University. A second collection allows tracking of biological development and a repeated measure of experienced stress (cortisol). By investigating the interaction between stress, biology, and culture, we move toward understanding the factors associated with developmental plasticity and the timing of life history events, as well as their contributions to the evolution of human childhood. The results of this study will be valuable to multiple fields, including biocultural anthropology, child development, and cognitive psychology. It will further add to ethnographic data on childhood among two small-scale societies and foster continued collaboration with the University of Bangui. This grant will help to advance the scientific training of a promising graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Courtney Helfrecht has completed her research and successfully defended her dissertation, “Effects of Stress on Onset of Middle Childhood among Sidama Agropastoralists,” which was supported by a NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. Helfrecht’s research was initiated among Aka forest foragers and Ngandu horticulturalists of the Central African Republic but, due to the ongoing civil war, she conducted her research project in Ethiopia. There, she worked with Sidama agropastoralists in the Sidama Zone of the Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples’ Region.

 

During the award period, Helfrecht collected data on age categories, social and cognitive development during middle childhood (5-12 years old), and cultural/physical stressors from both adults and children. In addition, hair samples from 160 children (aged 3-18 years old) were collected to assess two biomarkers (cortisol and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate [DHEAS]), along with anthropometrics and demographic data.  Cortisol is a widely-used marker of stress. Rising DHEAS production is indicative of adrenarche, the event that marks onset of biological middle childhood. Helfrecht undertook hair hormone analysis on these samples, as well as an additional 320 samples that she previously collected from her Aka and Ngandu participants (160/population), to evaluate stress and adrenarche. Hair provides a time-averaged picture of hormones, allowing researchers to look at an individual’s hormonal phenotype using a single sample. Helfrecht’s samples represent one of the largest used for hair hormone analysis to date, particularly among children.

 

Middle childhood was long thought to be a ‘latent’ period where little of developmental significance occurred; however, it is now known that extensive social, cognitive, and physiological changes take place during this phase. Indeed, many of the benefits attributed to the evolution of our extended childhood—such as brain development, continued growth, sociocultural competency, cognitive development, and skill acquisition—commence at the onset of middle childhood. Understanding the effects of physical and social stressors during this phase of development is the ultimate objective of Helfrecht’s research, particularly as prolonged stress during childhood has lifelong implications.

 

Physical and social stressors both operate through the same biological axis, resulting in elevated levels of cortisol. One component of Helfrecht’s research examines the relationship between stress and the biological event associated with middle childhood, adrenarche. As noted above, adrenarche is a developmental event that typically occurs around age 7 and that is marked by rising levels of the hormone DHEAS (produced in the adrenal glands). DHEAS has significant effects on brain development, ranging from enhanced memory and learning ability to habituation of the stress response.

 

Key results indicated that, as in most cultures, onset of Sidama middle childhood (shiima beto) coincides with onset of reasoning ability. The primary stressor believed to affect children at the time of this research (rainy season) is a shortage of economic resources, and the impact of this is reflected in hair cortisol concentrations (HCC). Average age of onset for adrenarche is slightly delayed in comparison to Western populations, but examination of the associated biomarker (DHEAS) revealed an unexpected pattern. The adrenal fetal zone (responsible for prenatal production of DHEAS) normally disappears within a few months of birth. Here, DHEAS production is still high among young children, suggesting that the regression of this zone is significantly delayed. This indicates important variation from known patterns of development.
